Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 07:17PM Debbi5108 wrote: Stef58, sorry you are here in this situation but, you have came to the right place due to the fact the women on here have helped me as well as others tremendously.   If they get a clean margin usually they do not go back in and take any more nodes and it was only in 1 of 6 which is good and you had a masectomy which again this is good I had 7 out of 12 nodes with it and they didn't go back in and I also had my tissue expanders (TE abbreviated) put in and they left them also went on with the fills even though I was going to do radiation, I know all of this is so overwhelming however we are all here for you and if I can be of any help please feel free to PM me. okay
Posts.Title: What happens if in lymph system? stef58 Seabee

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 06:50PM Debbi5108 wrote: Cherneski,      Hope I spelled that right.  First Off I want to say that I too was a Smoker however the day I had surgery was also the day I quit, that being said I too when diagnosed started chain smoking (although I had almost quit) I talked with the Onco, BS and PS and all told me that as much as they would prefer me to quit they understood what kind of stress I was feeling and asked that I consider trying to quit however not one refused to do their job that I was paying for just because I was a smoker!!!! I am so sorry that you are being treated that way.  I will say that if you want to quit you will when you are ready.  As for why we have TE's I can tell you that the reason I have mine is I had a Bi-lat on 2/24 with immediate expanders (also the day I quit smoking), I will have my exchange (they remove expanders and put implants in) approx. August after my rads are over. I stayed in the hospital over night and 40lbs won't happen for quite some time. Although some say no reconstruction after rads my PS said yes they can be done however they do like to expand you before hand but, it can be done after as well but will be at a much slower pace and maybe not as big.  Hair falling out due to chemo usually happens around day 13-18 (mine the 17th day) Could you maybe not lose it?? I suppose so but, not likely and yes it sucks to lose it but, IT DOES GROW BACK.  My last chemo was 1/26 and my hair started growing back during my last chemo TX's  How long you are out of commision after surgery depends on you for me not long, Pain I wouldn't say I was in Pain very uncomfortable for approx. 3 or 4 days then mildly uncomfortable for 3-5 then it gradually got better day by day or at least it did for me.  I hope I have helped in some small way as I remember wanting these same questions answered and some of these very same wonderful ladies helped me out and Lovinmomma made me laugh at a time I wanted to ball so Momma Thank You, I am currently doing rads 2 down 28 more to go and never thought I would make it past Chemo but, I did and partly because of your words of encouragement. Another Deb

But I agree with Anna everyone is different and it doesn't matter if you gain a few however that being said try not to lose any.  Steroids may puff you up but that goes away after treatment is done

Posts.Title: Tanning after Radiation Jeanne_D Jeanne_D

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 04:35AM Debbi5108 wrote: Not to fuel anyones fire, however I agree that it is every individuals choice as to tan or not to tan I myself use tanning as a help with arthritis as well as psoriasis and have been told by my ortho doctor that this is beneficial for me especially in the winter months however that being said I understand that those of you who do not tan because they are afraid of skin cancer have a valid point as well but, honestly there are just as many worries from the real sun as there is with tanning and you can use protection with both tanning strategies I.E. SUN SCREEN!!!! I am by no means attacking either side as I am a tanner myself and have been a manager of a tanning salon in the past and enjoyed it immensely but, I will tell you that if we as humans stopped participating in activities for fear of getting cancer then you would be surprised of just what you  couldn't, shouldn't or wouldn't do any longer like get X-rays, drink a glass of wine or eat certain foods, as well as what you could , should or would do to prevent cancer like eating certain foods you may not find very appetizing or activities that could cause you to fight off the ability of cancer cells from growing as well as if you lived a good clean life with no bad habits or having the perfect metabolism in order to ward off this awful beast however, I don't think it is possible to be perfect or do everything right therefore all we can do is the best we can and hope for the best but, mainly we just have to stay vigilant and become aware of the changes in our bodies. Yes I am a tanner always have been probably always will be however that being said I will just do it wisely as will all they others as I presume like me they do not want any type of cancer and every cancer has its own set nof issues one has to deal with. I truly hope I have not offended others however if I did it was done unintentional. Hugs, Debbi

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 05:00PM Debbi5108 wrote: Janet,      I totally agree with you on everything.  I too feel they should give us our options and then when we make our choice RESPECT it and if they don't agree explain as to why and discuss stats with us and such but, ultimately let us make the decision.  After speaking personally with the pathologist about my cancer and choices I decided to have a bi-lat mas and he told me that I was probably one of the smartest woman my age (43 at the time) he had met, that made me feel really good.  My onco however makes me question myself not that he isn't sweet and good but, in the beginning he said 4 A/C then 10 Taxol then he decided 12 Taxol and acted as if he never said 10 trust me Chemo brain and all I remember what he said and so did my husband.  I have 4 more to go and really only want to do 2 more and have decided to talk to him in regards to this mattter tomorrow after my 9th Chemo. I don't want to do Tamoxifen myself and since I am having a Bi-Lat don't really understand why I should except from what I have read here about being ER/PR+ I guess its standard and I will probably at least try it however if I develope serious or nauseating side effects I will not continue to take it although I am curious to see what he has to say about it and my score if he can not answer those questions or explain to me why it will benefit me to take it I may not take it to begin with.  Janet since yours what caught early I take it you did not have to do Chemo is this correct?  Also with it being in the nodes I was told that made for a stage 2 or did I misunderstand, however I have IDC not DCIS so that could be the difference. Thank you for the reply and making me feel I am not as stupid as I felt and I say Make YOUR decision and as long as it is something you can live with than that is all that matters. Hugs, Deb

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2009 08:01PM Debbi5108 wrote: Hello All,      I had my Bi-Lat on 2/24 and to be honest, it wasn't as bad as I had thought it would be, Yes I am sore and yes I feel pressure but, it is so doable.  Went to see the PS on 3/5 and got all 3 of my drains out plus he did my first fill of 50 cc each, wasn't expecting any  of that especially so soon therefore I hadn't taken a tylenol let alone a pain pill and I didn't find it a horrible thing to endure matter of fact it was over before I knew it. I asked about doing reconstruction while doing Rads and his answer was as long as they weren't radiating the breast he could continue with my fills which I mam being told they will radiate the clavicle area only for precautionary purposes, so I guess all is well or as well as can be, also I didnt have to have both breast taken but, chose to as not to have to relive this possibly in 2-5 years as I have seen happen to others I know.  Hope each and everyone is well and If there are any other questions I can ask my doctors let me know cause I go see my BS Monday and will gladly ask any you might have as luckily she is also my friend. Chat at You nall soon and Thanks for all your encouraging words You Gals are the Greatest, Deb

Posts.Content: May 8, 2009 11:31PM Debbi5108 wrote: KerryMac, Yeah You are done with your dreaded, Nasty, awful I could go on Chemo haha!!!!  The hair will start growing quickly or at least mine has.  Don't know if it is because of the horse shampoo or not but, I continue to use it and it continues to grow pretty fast and its getting thicker.  My hair use to be straight and still is, no curls here the only difference is color, I have always been a white blond ( naturally) and now I have very dark hair with some red, weird eh? Going topless is wonderful and to be honest I thought I'd be more selfconcious than I am, matter of fact I forget about it, you know I think there is good in everything and every situation and the BC situation has made me realize life is way to fragile and precious to waste time worrying what someone will think or how someone will react to my hair do or lack thereof and that is a good thing that has come from my diagnosis.  Bad things come too however, I like to ignore the LOL. By The way Your daughter looked adorable in your wig.  My great nephew likes to put mine on (Worrisome???? Just a little LOL)when he comes over and the bad thing is he looks better in it than I, My granddaughter who is seven has never asked but, then again I think she tries ti give me normalcy.  Okay will stop going on and on just a little lonely tonight I guess and a little down. Thanks for letting me have somewhere to go and just talk. Deb

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2008 08:13AM Debbi5108 wrote: Michelle, first off, let me say I understand your fear however they will numb the area and you will not feel a thing or at least I didn't.  I am the type that likes to watch whats going on and was allowed to, which made me feel better it was painless actually taking the steri strips off a few days after the biopsy hurt worse LOL. they may even give you something to calm you either but pill or IV but, I would ask now so as to alleviate the fears you have. as for the wire location I know nothing about that if they did that to me I was numb and didn't know but, they did biopsy both the tumor in my left breast as well as the node in my armpit area I believe and like I said painless. Make the call thats what they are there for and why you have to pay the big bucks. You can ask for anything!!!! and they will do what they think is best and believe me they want to keep you calm and happy. Good luck keep me updated you can send me private messages if you want.
